item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Kicks Off 2025 “Shop With A Cop” Holiday Program
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Police Department kicks off its 2025 Shop With A Cop program, pairing officers with children for a holiday shopping experience.
item.content:encoded:
The holiday season is all about giving — and once again, the Atlantic City Police Department is helping make the season brighter for local families through its annual Shop With A Cop program.

Kicking off on December 15, the three-day initiative brings together Atlantic City police officers, children, and community partners for a meaningful holiday experience rooted in kindness, connection, and support. The 2025 program is being held at Walmart in Egg Harbor Township in partnership with O.C.E.A.N., Inc. and Walmart.

Building Joy — and Trust — One Shopping Trip at a Time

Each day from 9:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. (December 15, 16, and 17), participating children are paired one-on-one with Atlantic City police officers for a special holiday shopping experience. Together, they browse the aisles, pick out gifts, and share conversation — creating moments that are both joyful and meaningful.

More than just a shopping trip, Shop With A Cop is designed to foster positive relationships between youth and law enforcement in a relaxed, welcoming environment. By spending time together outside of traditional law-enforcement settings, officers and children have the opportunity to connect on a personal level — building trust and understanding that can last well beyond the holidays.

A Tradition Rooted in Community Care

Shop With A Cop has long been a cherished community initiative in Atlantic City. Officers volunteer their time to participate, reflecting a shared commitment to supporting families and showing young people that law enforcement is deeply invested in their well-being.

With the support of partners like O.C.E.A.N., Inc. and Walmart, the program helps ensure that children and families can experience the joy of the season while feeling seen, supported, and valued.

Spreading Holiday Spirit Across the City

As Atlantic City continues to celebrate the season through parades, markets, and community events, Shop With A Cop stands out as a powerful reminder of the impact that compassion and collaboration can have.

It’s moments like these — small in scale but big in heart — that define what it means to be a community. And once again, Atlantic City is showing that the holidays are about more than gifts; they’re about connection, care, and coming together.

item.title: Atlantic City Shines as Community Comes Together for Holiday Parade & Night Market
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Atlantic Avenue lit up with smiles, music, and holiday cheer as residents, families, and youth came together for Atlantic City’s Holiday Parade & Night Market — a celebration of community, pride, and seasonal joy.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City kicked off the holiday season in unforgettable fashion as residents, families, and visitors filled Atlantic Avenue for the Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Night Market, transforming a December evening into a celebration of community, pride, and seasonal joy.

As twilight settled in, Atlantic Avenue glowed with festive lights, music, and movement. Families lined the route bundled in scarves and hats, children waved with excitement, and neighbors greeted one another as floats, marching bands, dancers, and community organizations brought the holiday spirit to life. For the first time in years, the parade traveled down one of the city’s most iconic corridors, turning Atlantic Avenue into a ribbon of light, laughter, and shared celebration.

‍

Smiles, Spirit, and Youth at the Heart of the Celebration

One of the most powerful sights of the evening was the joy on display, especially among the city’s young people. Youth groups proudly marched, smiling faces lit up the street, and cheers echoed from block to block. The energy was unmistakable: Atlantic City showing up for itself.

From spontaneous laughter to proud group photos, the parade reflected what community traditions are meant to do, bring people together, across neighborhoods and generations, to celebrate something shared.

Atlantic Avenue didn’t just host a parade. It became a space of connection, belonging, and possibility.

A Night Market Full of Warmth and Community Pride

As the parade reached O’Donnell Memorial Park, the celebration continued with the debut of the Holiday Night Market. Under twinkling lights, families and friends strolled through the festive village, browsing handcrafted gifts, enjoying seasonal treats, and sipping hot chocolate while supporting local vendors.

The Night Market quickly became a gathering place, where conversations lingered, music filled the air, and the spirit of the season felt personal and close to home. It was the perfect complement to the parade, extending the evening into a shared experience rooted in local pride and small business support.

‍

‍

A Vision Realized Through Collective Effort

This year’s expanded parade reflected a bold vision: bringing the celebration directly through the heart of the city. What some initially questioned became a moment of collective accomplishment, made possible by coordination, teamwork, and belief in what Atlantic City could pull off together.

The success of the evening was the result of a true citywide effort, supported by the Special Events team, Public Safety, Public Works, community engagement teams, Visit Atlantic City, partners, volunteers, performers, and participants who all played a role in making the night seamless and memorable.

And the momentum is just beginning. Plans are already underway to expand the parade even further next year, with a longer route, larger staging area, and even more participants, building on the energy and success felt throughout Atlantic Avenue this season.

A Moment That Belonged to the City

What unfolded during the Holiday Parade & Night Market was more than a seasonal event. It was a reminder of what happens when a city believes in itself and shows up together.

Atlantic City didn’t just celebrate the holidays, it celebrated community, resilience, and the joy that comes from shared moments. As the lights dimmed and the crowds headed home, one thing was clear: the spirit felt along Atlantic Avenue will linger well beyond the season.

Because when Atlantic City comes together, it’s always a Great Day.

item.title: Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market Returns December 13 — A Full Day of Festive Fun for the Whole City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City’s Holiday Parade & Market returns on December 13 with a full day of festive fun — from a Winter Wonderland Festival to a twilight parade down Atlantic Avenue and a Holiday Village of local vendors, treats, and community chee
item.content:encoded:
The holiday spirit is taking over Atlantic City once again! On Saturday, December 13, 2025, the City’s beloved Holiday Parade returns — and this year, it’s bigger, brighter, and more magical than ever.

The annual tradition is expanding into the Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market, a day-long celebration that will transform the city into a winter wonderland filled with glowing floats, local vendors, live entertainment, and plenty of seasonal cheer.

Winter Wonderland Festival Kicks Off the Day

Before the parade even begins, families can join the Atlantic City Youth Services Winter Wonderland Festival at Skate Zone (501 N. Albany Avenue) from 12:00 PM to 4:00 PM.
Enjoy food, games, rides, and winter-themed activities — the ideal warm-up for an evening of city-wide celebration.

A Twilight Parade to Light Up Atlantic Avenue

For the first time in years, the parade will travel the full length of Atlantic Avenue at twilight, setting the city aglow with sparkling lights and festive music.

The procession kicks off at 4:30 PM outside City Hall on South Carolina Avenue and makes its way to Albany Avenue, featuring community groups, marching bands, and dazzling floats that celebrate Atlantic City’s creativity and hometown pride.

A Holiday Market at O’Donnell Memorial Park

When the parade ends, the celebration continues! From 4:00 to 8:00 PM, O’Donnell Memorial Park will host the Atlantic City Holiday Market — a charming Holiday Village showcasing:

  • Local artisans and handcrafted gifts
  • Hot chocolate and holiday bites
  • Seasonal treats and family-friendly fun

It’s the perfect finale to a night that captures everything special about the season in Atlantic City: community, culture, and connection.

‍

Be Part of the Magic

There’s still time to join in!

  • Parade Registration:  Marching bands, community groups, and local businesses can register to participate in the Holiday Parade
  • Market Registration:  Vendors can apply for a spot at the Holiday Market

Contact the City of Atlantic City Special Events Office at (609) 347-5823 with questions.

A Celebration That Brings Atlantic City Together

From the Winter Wonderland Festival in the afternoon to the glowing parade and festive market at night, Saturday, December 13 is shaping up to be one of the most joyful days of the year in Atlantic City.

Bundle up, bring your friends and family, and experience a can’t-miss community tradition that will fill your heart with holiday joy and Atlantic City pride.

Because when Atlantic City celebrates together, it’s always a Great Day.

item.title: Atlantic City Staff United to Support Residents in Need
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic CIty Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City showcased its commitment to community care as staff from Multicultural Affairs and Senior Services worked together to prepare and package meals for residents in need. Their efforts reflected true compassion and a deep dedication to serving the community.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City demonstrated an inspiring display of teamwork and compassion this week as staff came together to support residents who needed an extra helping hand. What began as a simple initiative quickly became a meaningful reminder of the city’s deep-rooted commitment to public service.

Staff from both the Multicultural Affairs and Senior Services Department teamed up to prepare and package meals for community members who required additional support. Their collective effort reflected the city’s long-standing mission to uplift and care for its residents, especially the most vulnerable.

The Multicultural Affairs team played a significant role by ensuring that the initiative reached residents from diverse cultural backgrounds. Their understanding of community needs allowed the project to remain inclusive and accessible to all.

Meanwhile, the Senior Services Department focused on identifying and serving older residents who needed immediate assistance. Their hands-on involvement ensured that meals were organized, prepared, and distributed efficiently and with genuine care.

This initiative was far more than a routine task. It served as a powerful expression of the city’s commitment to compassion, unity, and service. Preparing meals became a symbol of the city’s belief that serving the community is not just part of the job—it is a core value and a reflection of who they are.

Throughout the week, the dedication of the teams was evident. From gathering supplies to coordinating distribution, every step was carried out with professionalism and heart. Their work showed that the spirit of service remains strong within the city workforce.

Residents who received the meals expressed their gratitude, noting how much it meant to feel seen, supported, and cared for. For many, this effort was a reminder that they are part of a community that continues to look after one another.

In the end, the City of Atlantic City extended its heartfelt appreciation to the incredible teams who made this initiative possible. Their actions highlighted the true meaning of public service—stepping up with compassion, empathy, and unwavering dedication to the people they serve.

item.title: Absecon Lighthouse Kicked Off the Holiday Season with Festive Cheer
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic CIty Contributors
item.description: The Absecon Lighthouse welcomed the holiday season with festive decor throughout the museum, gift shop, and up the 228 steps to the top. Volunteers’ efforts created a magical holiday experience for visitors to enjoy.
item.content:encoded:
The Absecon Lighthouse officially welcomed the holiday season, transforming the historic site into a festive wonderland for visitors. Volunteers played an essential role in bringing the holiday spirit to life, decorating the museum, gift shop, and all public areas throughout the lighthouse.

Their dedication reached all the way up the 228 steps, where they carefully installed enormous wreaths at the top, creating a stunning seasonal display visible throughout the historic structure. The result was a magical atmosphere that delighted visitors and the local community alike.

Each ornament, wreath, and decorative element reflected the volunteers’ hard work and enthusiasm, adding warmth and cheer to the lighthouse. The collaborative effort highlighted not only the beauty of the decorations but also the strong sense of community among lighthouse supporters.

Although the Absecon Lighthouse was closed on Thanksgiving Day, staff encouraged guests to visit starting Friday, November 28, to experience the holiday magic firsthand. Visitors could explore the museum, enjoy the gift shop, and take in the festive displays that celebrated the season in true Atlantic City style.

Volunteers and staff worked together seamlessly to ensure that all decorations were both beautiful and safely installed throughout the historic building. Their efforts showcased the importance of community involvement in preserving the charm and appeal of the lighthouse while creating memorable experiences for all.

The festive transformation of the Absecon Lighthouse demonstrated how volunteer dedication and community spirit could bring joy to thousands of visitors. From the smallest ornaments to the monumental wreaths at the top, every detail contributed to the holiday atmosphere.

The lighthouse team expressed gratitude to the volunteers whose efforts made the seasonal celebration possible. Their work not only brightened the historic site but also strengthened community bonds, reminding everyone of the power of collaboration and festive cheer.

Visitors were encouraged to bring friends and family to enjoy the holiday decorations, learn about the lighthouse’s history, and take in the stunning views from the top. The seasonal transformation added a unique and memorable layer to the Atlantic City experience.

In the end, the holiday celebration at the Absecon Lighthouse stood as a testament to volunteer dedication, creativity, and community pride. The festive displays left a lasting impression on all who visited, setting the tone for a joyful holiday season.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Strengthened Community Bonds at the Annual PAL Thanksgiving Dinner

As the event came to a close, the Atlantic City Police Department expressed heartfelt gratitude to everyone involved—from organizers to volunteers to families who attended. Their collective efforts reflected the true spirit of Atlantic City: caring, supportive, and united.

item.title: Brighton Avenue School’s Generosity Shined Through a Community Food Drive

item.description: Brighton Avenue School partnered with the Office of Multicultural Services and the Spanish Community Center to deliver donated canned goods to families in need. The effort showcased true community spirit and the power of working together to make a meaningful impact.

The initiative demonstrated the school’s commitment to supporting local families and contributing to the well-being of the broader community.

The effort served as a strong example of compassion in action. Students and educators worked together with purpose, gathering canned goods that would later provide essential support to households in need. Their participation reflected a deep understanding of the importance of service and helping others.

The Office of Multicultural Services proudly acted as a bridge between Brighton Avenue School and the Spanish Community Center, ensuring that the donated items were delivered safely and directly to the families who needed them most. This partnership strengthened the impact of the initiative and showcased how collaboration can elevate community outreach.

The Spanish Community Center, which hosted a monthly food distribution program, welcomed the donations as a valuable contribution to their ongoing efforts. For many families facing food insecurity, this support provided much-needed relief and stability.

The teamwork between the school, the Office of Multicultural Services, and the Spanish Community Center highlighted how unified efforts could create meaningful change within Atlantic City. Each organization brought its own strengths to the initiative, resulting in a smooth and impactful process.

Students also benefitted from this experience, gaining firsthand insight into the power of generosity and community service. The school staff modeled empathy and leadership, reinforcing values that extend far beyond the classroom.

The Office of Multicultural Services expressed deep gratitude to everyone involved, acknowledging that acts like this represented the true spirit of Atlantic City—neighbors supporting neighbors, schools giving back, and organizations working together toward a shared mission.

This food drive stood as a testament to what community looked like: people coming together, offering compassion, and creating positive change with thoughtful and heartfelt contributions.

In the end, the generosity of Brighton Avenue School and the partnership with the Spanish Community Center created a meaningful impact, reminding Atlantic City that collaboration and kindness can go a long way in uplifting families and strengthening the community as a whole.

By the end of the event, it was clear that this year marked a remarkable chapter for the Mini Hoops participants. Atlantic City Recreation expressed appreciation for the community’s support and reaffirmed its commitment to continuing programs that uplift and encourage Atlantic City’s youth.

item.title: Atlantic City High School Completed Its Thanksgiving in a Bag Community Initiative
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City High School completed its Thanksgiving in a Bag initiative, delivering 76 food and turkey packages to students and families with the support of local donors, sororities, and fraternities. The project demonstrated the community’s commitment to uplifting families during the holiday season.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City High School successfully wrapped up its Thanksgiving in a Bag project, a heartfelt community effort led by the Atlantic City High School (Hope4AC) program and the Dual Credit Service Learning Class. This initiative brought together students, staff, community donors, and local organizations with one shared goal: to support families in need during the Thanksgiving season.

The school extended its gratitude to everyone who contributed food items, helping ensure that students and their families received meaningful support. These donations played a crucial role in making the project a success and demonstrated the strong sense of community within Atlantic City.

A significant contribution came from the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, whose members generously donated 46 turkeys. Their support greatly expanded the school’s ability to reach more families. The effort was further strengthened by the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, which added 10 turkeys to the initiative.

In addition to these organizational donations, Atlantic City High School also received 20 turkeys, bringing the total number of turkeys to distribute to families to an impressive 76. Between last Friday and the day of final distribution, the school completed all 76 deliveries, ensuring that students and their families received a full Thanksgiving package.

Each delivery included a turkey accompanied by a bag of food, all of which had been donated by members of the school community and generous partners. These bags ensured families could prepare a complete holiday meal, providing comfort and support during the season of gratitude.

The initiative showcased the power of collaboration and service, reflecting the school’s ongoing commitment to supporting students beyond academics. By bringing together local organizations, volunteers, and donors, Atlantic City High School demonstrated what can be achieved when a community unites with purpose.

The school expressed heartfelt appreciation to every individual and group whose generosity made the Thanksgiving in a Bag initiative possible. Their collective effort helped brighten the holiday season for dozens of families and reinforced the spirit of giving that defines the Atlantic City community.

‍

Photo Credit: Atlantic City High School

item.title: Operation Warm Brings Joy and Coats to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Operation Warm distributed 450 brand-new coats to students at Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex, ensuring they stayed warm and supported during winter. The initiative highlighted the generosity of local sponsors and its mission to provide warmth, confidence, and hope to children in need.
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, November 13, 2025, the gymnasium at Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex was filled with excitement as Operation Warm distributed 450 brand-new coats to students, ensuring they would stay warm during the winter months. The event reflected a heartwarming effort to support local children and provide basic needs during a challenging season.

The distribution was sponsored by Allstate Insurance Agent Marc A. Ludwig of Northfield, NJ, and Ludwig Financial Group, demonstrating a strong commitment to the community. The initiative brought together students, staff, and volunteers to celebrate the generosity and care of local partners.

Superintendent of Schools Dr. La'Quetta S. Small expressed gratitude for the donation, noting that the act of kindness ensured students were warm, supported, and ready to learn. She also commended administrators, teachers, and school staff for their coordination and dedication, which helped make the distribution a success and highlighted the district’s commitment to caring for the whole child.

Principal Jodi Burroughs said the students were overjoyed by the gifts. She emphasized that the initiative helped parents during a time when costs for food, clothing, and essentials were rising, and praised community partners for their support and collaboration.

Heather Connolly, Vice President of Partnerships for Operation Warm, highlighted the organization’s mission to provide warmth, confidence, and hope. She explained that the program connects under-resourced children with what they need to thrive, ensuring every student left with a brand-new coat.

The gymnasium buzzed with anticipation as students entered class by class. Tables were arranged with coats in all sizes and a variety of vibrant colors, allowing children to select their favorite and make the experience personal and exciting.

After choosing their coats, students visited the Allstate table to personalize their jackets by writing their names inside, transforming each gift into a token of care and support. This simple act created a lasting memory and reinforced the message of community involvement.

Amy Vanrell, Director of Operations for Ludwig Financial Group, highlighted the organization’s long-term dedication to service. Over the past nine years, the Allstate Foundation and Ludwig Financial Group had donated over $100,000 and served more than 7,500 students in the Atlantic City school district, ensuring that every child had a warm coat for cold days.

Beyond the physical gift of coats, the program imparted confidence, comfort, and hope to students. The combination of generous sponsors and dedicated volunteers created an experience that extended far beyond the gymnasium.

Thanks to Operation Warm and its partners, hundreds of students left the event prepared for the winter months, carrying with them not only warm coats but also the joy of knowing their community cared deeply about their well-being.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Announces Promotions and Appointment
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department promoted Officers Christopher Smith and Lauren Downey to Sergeant and welcomed retired Officer Jimmy Bower as a Special Law Enforcement Officer. These appointments highlighted the department’s commitment to recognizing leadership, experience, and continued service to the city.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department announced the promotion of Officers Christopher Smith and Lauren Downey to the rank of Sergeant, along with the swearing-in of retired ACPD Officer Jimmy Bower as a Special Law Enforcement Officer assigned to the Atlantic City Municipal Court. These personnel changes reflected the department’s ongoing commitment to recognizing leadership, experience, and dedication among its officers.

Sergeant Christopher Smith had served with the Atlantic City Police Department since 2007. His promotion to sergeant was in recognition of his years of dedicated service, expertise in law enforcement, and leadership within the department.

Sergeant Lauren Downey, who joined the department in 2001, earned her promotion through consistent excellence, professionalism, and her commitment to community policing initiatives. Both sergeants were acknowledged for their leadership and contributions to maintaining public safety in Atlantic City.

In addition to the promotions, retired ACPD Officer Jimmy Bower was sworn in as a Special Law Enforcement Officer (SLEO). Officer Bower was assigned to the Atlantic City Municipal Court, where he provided law enforcement support and helped ensure safety within the judicial environment.

The swearing-in and promotion ceremonies underscored the department’s focus on leveraging the experience and expertise of its personnel to strengthen operations and leadership across all areas of law enforcement.

Officials from the department congratulated Sergeant Smith, Sergeant Downey, and Officer Bower, emphasizing the importance of their continued service to the city and their example of professional excellence for other officers.

These advancements also highlighted the department’s commitment to professional development, career growth, and cultivating leadership within its ranks.

Community members and colleagues recognized the achievements of the promoted sergeants and the newly appointed SLEO, celebrating their dedication to protecting and serving the citizens of Atlantic City.

The Atlantic City Police Department reaffirmed its dedication to excellence, public safety, and the growth of its personnel, highlighting the accomplishments of its officers as a testament to continued commitment and service.

With these promotions and appointments, the department strengthened its leadership team and reinforced its mission to serve the community with professionalism, integrity, and dedication.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City Senior Services Seniors Celebrate Year-End with Festive Outings

The celebration highlighted the importance of friendship, engagement, and joyful experiences for the city’s senior community.

Participants from the city’s Water Aerobics classes and Tech Classes joined together for the second annual year-end celebration, marking a memorable day filled with fun and friendship.

The day began with a visit to the Tree Lighting Ceremony at Tropicana, where seniors experienced the festive atmosphere, sparkling lights, and holiday cheer. The event offered an opportunity for social engagement and community connection, allowing participants to enjoy the season in a lively and welcoming environment.

The outings emphasized the importance of social and recreational activities in promoting wellness, mental stimulation, and overall quality of life for seniors. Staff members highlighted that these events were designed not only for enjoyment but also to reinforce connections among participants who regularly engage in city programs.

By combining festive celebrations with cultural experiences, Atlantic City Senior Services created an environment where seniors could relax, have fun, and feel recognized for their dedication to the programs they attended throughout the year.

The second annual year-end celebration built on the success of the previous year’s event, demonstrating the city’s ongoing commitment to providing meaningful and enriching experiences for its senior residents.

Programs like Water Aerobics and Tech Classes continued to offer seniors opportunities for physical activity, cognitive engagement, and social interaction. These activities fostered friendships, lifelong learning, and a sense of community among participants.

Throughout the day, seniors expressed gratitude for the events and excitement for future opportunities to participate in city-sponsored programs. The combination of camaraderie, festive atmosphere, and entertainment made the celebration a highlight of the year.

Atlantic City Senior Services emphasized that such initiatives were essential in supporting seniors’ overall well-being while creating memorable experiences that strengthened connections among participants.

As the celebration concluded, seniors left with smiles, renewed friendships, and anticipation for next year’s activities, reflecting the city’s commitment to enhancing the quality of life for its senior community.

item.title: Atlantic City Youth Services Concluded a Successful College & Career Week
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Youth Services wrapped up a successful College & Career Week, uniting schools, colleges, and local businesses to support and inspire students. The week highlighted the city’s dedication to MAKING WAVES for youth through meaningful opportunities and community partnership.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Youth Services concluded a meaningful and inspiring week-long celebration of College & Career Week, an initiative designed to guide local students as they explored academic paths and professional opportunities. The series of events brought together schools, colleges, community partners, and local businesses that collectively helped prepare students for their future goals.

Throughout the week, students engaged with representatives from various colleges across the region who provided insight into admissions, academic programs, scholarship options, and the overall college experience. Their participation offered students a clearer understanding of the possibilities available after high school.

Local businesses also played an important role by sharing real-world knowledge about workplace expectations, career development, and industry pathways. Their involvement reinforced the connection between local youth and the broader economic community.

Atlantic City Youth Services expressed deep appreciation to everyone who participated and contributed to the week’s success. item.title: Latin Rhythms by the Sea: Honoring the Legacy of Latin Music in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Latin Rhythms by the Sea exhibit brought the history of Latin music in Atlantic City to life, highlighting iconic performers and the lasting impact of their sound. Visitors experienced a powerful tribute to the rhythms that once filled the city’s most vibrant stages.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Experience unveiled its newest exhibit, Latin Rhythms by the Sea, offering the public an immersive look into the vibrant history of Latin music and its influence on Atlantic City’s entertainment scene. The exhibit, which was officially placed on display by the Atlantic City Free Public Library, celebrated the performers who once filled the city’s venues with rhythm, energy, and cultural pride.

Showcasing an impressive array of photographs, stories, and memorabilia, the exhibit highlighted the achievements of legendary Latin artists such as Miguelito Valdés, Xavier Cugat, and Tito Puente. These iconic performers drew enormous crowds, inspiring audiences to rise from their seats and dance along to the infectious beat of their bands. Their contributions played a significant role in shaping Atlantic City’s musical identity throughout the mid-20th century.

Through detailed displays and authentic archival material, Latin Rhythms by the Sea illustrated how these artists bridged cultures and brought people together through music. Their performances not only entertained but also fostered a deeper appreciation of Latin heritage within the community. By placing these stories at the forefront, the Atlantic City Experience underscored the city’s longstanding connection to diverse artistic traditions.

The exhibit was developed as a special project of the Foundation of the Atlantic City Free Public Library, reflecting the library’s ongoing commitment to preserving and celebrating the city’s cultural history. As part of its mission, the library aimed to create opportunities for residents and visitors to engage with Atlantic City’s rich archival legacy.

Presented by the Atlantic City Free Public Library, the Atlantic City Experience was housed inside the lobby of Jim Whelan Boardwalk Hall, where the exhibit remained open to the public. Open Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., the installation offered free admission, ensuring accessible learning for all who wished to explore the stories of these musical pioneers.

Through Latin Rhythms by the Sea, Atlantic City honored the artistry, passion, and legacy of the Latin performers who helped define its cultural landscape. Their music left an indelible mark on the city, and this exhibit served as a tribute to the rhythms that once echoed along its shores.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Officers Honored for Valor at Annual Awards Ceremony
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department had been honored by the 200 Club of Atlantic and Cape May Counties for exemplary valor and service. The ceremony also marked the first presentation of the "Sergeant Eric Wise Memorial Award," given to Detective Eric Evans in tribute to Sergeant Wise’s lasting contributions.
item.content:encoded:
Members of the Atlantic City Police Department were formally recognized on Thursday night for their outstanding service and bravery during the annual Valor Awards Ceremony hosted by the 200 Club of Atlantic and Cape May Counties. The event highlighted the dedication and courage of first responders who had gone above and beyond in the protection of the community.

The 200 Club of Atlantic and Cape May Counties, a long-standing non-profit organization, has remained committed to providing financial assistance to the families of police, fire, and rescue personnel who have risked or lost their lives in the line of duty. Each year, the organization honors individuals who have displayed unquestionable valor when facing adversity and whose actions have made a meaningful difference in public safety.

During this year’s ceremony, several Atlantic City officers were commended for their distinguished service. Those honored included:

- Lieutenant James Herbert

- Sergeant Brian Hambrecht

- Sergeant Jonathan Walsh

- Officer Scott Sendrick

- Officer Melvin Murray III

- Officer Kyle Bender

- Detective Joshua Corona

a member of the Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office who had been assigned to the ACPD. These officers were recognized not only for specific acts of bravery but also for their continued professionalism and unwavering commitment to protecting the residents of Atlantic City. Their recognition underscored the department’s collective dedication to service and the high standards upheld by its members.

A particularly meaningful moment in the ceremony came with the presentation of the inaugural "Sergeant Eric Wise Memorial Award". The award was given to Detective Eric Evans, who had the honor of being the first recipient. The presentation was made by Sergeant Wise’s wife, Antonia, adding emotional depth to the occasion.

The memorial award was established to recognize the narcotics detective of the year and to honor the legacy of Sergeant Eric Wise, a respected member of the Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office who had worked closely with the Atlantic City Police Department throughout his career. Sergeant Wise passed away earlier this year, and his memory was strongly felt during the ceremony.

The event served not only as a celebration of individual achievements but also as a tribute to the ongoing commitment of law enforcement personnel who continue to protect and serve with integrity and resolve. The evening reinforced the deep appreciation felt for those who dedicate their lives to safeguarding the community.

item.title: Atlantic City Launches Community Solar Initiative
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City launched a Community Solar initiative that allowed residents to save up to 15 percent on their electric bills. The program delivered immediate savings with no need for homeowners to install solar panels on their own properties.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City announced a major step forward in expanding clean energy access and reducing household expenses with the launch of its Community Solar initiative. The program, introduced under Mayor Marty Small Sr., offered residents the opportunity to lower their electric bills by up to 15 percent.

Through a competitive Request for Proposals process, the city awarded a community solar contract to HESP Solar, a provider selected to construct and manage new solar energy infrastructure across key municipal properties. As part of the project, solar canopies were installed at the City Hall employee parking lot on Arctic Avenue and the Public Works Complex parking lot on Albany Avenue.

These installations were designed to generate locally sourced solar energy that directly supported the program. Residents who chose to opt in were able to receive immediate savings on their monthly electric bills. One of the program’s most significant advantages was that residents did not need to install panels on their own homes, making clean energy participation accessible to renters, homeowners, and households of all income levels.

City officials highlighted the initiative as part of Atlantic City’s broader efforts to promote sustainability, energy resilience, and financial relief for families. By collaborating with HESP Solar, the city demonstrated its commitment to building partnerships that deliver long-term economic and environmental benefits to the community.

The Community Solar initiative stood as a notable achievement in Atlantic City’s ongoing push to provide residents with practical, cost-saving solutions while advancing its clean energy goals.

item.title: Atlantic City Black Business Directory: Empowering Local Entrepreneurs
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: The Atlantic City Black Business Directory celebrates and uplifts Black entrepreneurs across the city, fostering visibility, collaboration, and empowerment. It serves as both a resource and a movement — highlighting the creativity, resilience, and strength of Atlantic City’s Black business community.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City’s proud history of Black entrepreneurship is taking center stage once again. Following the success of the Black Business Expo, the City of Atlantic City has released the Atlantic City Black Business Directory 2025 — a resource designed to spotlight, support, and strengthen Black-owned businesses throughout the city.

The new directory serves not only as a guide to local goods and services but also as a tribute to the generations of Black entrepreneurs who helped shape Atlantic City’s cultural and economic foundation.

A Legacy of Enterprise and Resilience

For more than a century, Atlantic City has been home to a vibrant community of Black-owned businesses. During the early and mid-20th century, the city’s Northside neighborhood thrived as a hub of entrepreneurship and civic pride.

According to Ralph Hunter, founder of the African American Heritage Museum of Southern New Jersey, the 80-square-block Northside “was once a thriving community of businesses, entrepreneurs, and professionals — including doctors, lawyers, dentists, and funeral directors.”

In a segregated America, Atlantic City’s Black residents built parallel systems of success. They opened hotels, restaurants, and entertainment venues that welcomed travelers and performers excluded from white-only establishments.

Celebrating a New Chapter of Black Entrepreneurship

Today, that same entrepreneurial energy is alive again. The Atlantic City Black Business Directory 2025 builds on the success of the city’s Black Business Expo, held this summer at the All Wars Memorial Building. The Expo brought together dozens of local business owners, vendors, and community leaders for a night of networking, storytelling, and economic empowerment.

Now, the directory continues that momentum year-round, providing a one-stop resource for residents and visitors to discover and support Black-owned businesses across industries such as:

  • Food and beverage
  • Professional services
  • Retail and fashion
  • Health and wellness
  • Arts, entertainment, and event planning

The directory aims to make it easier than ever for consumers to #ShopLocal and invest in the businesses that make Atlantic City stronger.

A Living Tribute to Atlantic City’s Black Legacy

The Atlantic City Black Business Directory 2025 is more than a list — it’s a living tribute to the entrepreneurs who turned challenge into opportunity, and a reminder that the city’s progress is rooted in the strength of its people.

Whether you’re looking to hire a local service provider, dine at a Black-owned restaurant, or explore the city’s cultural heritage, the directory offers countless ways to celebrate, support, and sustain Atlantic City’s Black business community.

item.title: Free Atlantic City Programs Empowered Community Entrepreneurs to Succeed
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City hosted a series of free workshops in November 2025 to help residents enhance their career prospects and support local entrepreneurs. Through initiatives like the Resume Building Workshop, Path to Employment Workshop, and Media Skills for Entrepreneurs, the city continued empowering its community for long-term success.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City, under the leadership of Mayor Marty Small, Sr., continued its mission to empower residents by offering free programs designed to enhance career readiness and support local business growth. Through partnerships with community organizations and development offices, the city hosted a series of workshops and seminars in November 2025 that helped participants gain valuable skills and opportunities.

One of the highlighted initiatives was the Resume Building Workshop held on November 12th. Organized by the City of Atlantic City’s Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program under the CDBG office, in collaboration with Jewish Family Service (JFS), the event guided participants in creating professional resumes, discovering job leads, and receiving targeted training to increase employability. A follow-up session was also scheduled for December 9th at the PAL Building.

The Path to Employment Workshop, conducted on November 13th at the AtlantiCare Medical Arts Pavilion, brought together the City of Atlantic City Job Readiness & Employment Resource Program and Midtown CDC to provide comprehensive guidance on job preparedness. The workshop focused on helping residents boost confidence, explore career options, and strengthen their résumés. Participants also had another opportunity to join a similar workshop on December 18th.

For local entrepreneurs, the Media Skills for Entrepreneurs seminar offered practical training in public relations and brand promotion. Hosted by the City of Atlantic City Economic Development Office as part of the Planning and Development Seminar Series, this workshop took place on November 13th at Beat the Daily Grind Cafe. Attendees learned how to write compelling press releases, connect with media professionals, and strategically build brand visibility.

These programs reflected the city’s ongoing efforts to provide accessible and impactful learning opportunities. By collaborating with local organizations, Atlantic City demonstrated its strong commitment to fostering personal and professional growth among its residents.

The series not only supported job seekers but also created pathways for small business owners to thrive in the local economy. With resources like these, participants were able to enhance their skills and confidence, setting the stage for greater success in their respective fields.

Through consistent initiatives like the Planning and Development Seminar Series, the city proved that community collaboration and accessible education can create lasting change. Each session was a step forward in promoting economic development and empowering individuals to take control of their future.

By offering workshops focused on real-world needs—such as resume writing, job readiness, and media engagement—the City of Atlantic City continued to pave the way for a stronger, more connected community.

Residents who participated left equipped with the tools to pursue better opportunities, while entrepreneurs gained insights that would help their businesses stand out and grow sustainably.

These free programs exemplified Atlantic City’s dedication to supporting every member of the community—whether entering the workforce, changing careers, or growing a business.

item.title: November 2025 Great Day Gazette: Revitalizing, Celebrating, and Honoring Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: November was a month of revitalization, celebration, and community pride in Atlantic City. From major infrastructure upgrades to cultural recognition and heartfelt local events, the Great Day Gazette captured how the city continued to grow stronger together.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City continued its revitalization efforts this November, focusing on infrastructure, community connection, and celebration. Major updates, new programs, and heartwarming stories shaped another great month in the city’s journey toward progress and unity.

The city’s infrastructure saw significant improvements as Pacific Avenue joined the paving program, aligning with the ongoing Atlantic Avenue repaving project. The initiative was strengthened by a total of $5.3 million in NJDOT grant funding, supporting road enhancements and synchronized traffic signal upgrades across key corridors. Additionally, $684,708 was allocated for new pedestrian sidewalks along the Black Horse Pike, improving safety for students and families traveling between Atlantic City High School and Chelsea Heights.

Progress was also visible in other neighborhoods. The Baltic Avenue paving project neared completion, while the MLK Boulevard upgrade moved into the milling and paving phase. Meanwhile, construction reviews were underway for the Atlantic Avenue paving from Tennessee to Albany Avenues—marking another milestone in the city’s ongoing development plan.

Community spaces also came back to life with the long-awaited grand opening of Weekes Memorial Park. After years of careful restoration, this park once again became a welcoming gathering space for residents. The redesign featured landscaping, artistic displays, sustainable features, and accessibility upgrades, symbolizing the city’s commitment to safety, inclusion, and green living.

Listening to resident feedback, the Public Works Department installed additional stop signs at Winchester and Dover Avenues to ensure improved pedestrian and traffic safety—another example of how the city acted on community input to enhance neighborhood well-being.

The city celebrated the season with family-friendly festivities. Harvest Town filled Gardner’s Basin with music, games, costumes, and community resource tables, bringing together families for an afternoon of fun and connection. Likewise, Senior Services hosted a pumpkin decorating event, adding creativity and color to the fall spirit.

Fall evenings came alive at Bader Field during the Drive-In Movie & S’mores Night, where families gathered under the crisp night sky to enjoy a family film, fires, and free refreshments. The event also provided free winter hats and gloves, ensuring everyone stayed warm while celebrating together. Meanwhile, Atlantic City Recreation wrapped up another successful T-ball season, helping young athletes learn teamwork and skill in a positive environment.

Acts of heroism and recognition took center stage this month as well. The Atlantic City Police Foundation Hero Luncheon honored Sgt. Jonathan Walsh for saving a swimmer from drowning and Treasurer James Kutch for his years of dedicated service. During the same period, Officer Matt Schmidt received national attention for rescuing an injured canine from the icy October bay waters, showcasing the bravery and compassion of the city’s first responders.

Atlantic City also paid tribute to Rita and Anthony Mack, longtime business owners and community leaders, by dedicating a section of Arctic Avenue in their honor. For nearly four decades, the Macks provided employment, mentorship, and opportunities to countless residents through their McDonald’s franchises, making a lasting impact on the community they loved.

The city’s diversity and unity were celebrated as Mayor Marty Small Sr. and the Office of Multicultural Services received the Diaspora Excellence Award from Rediscover Africa 2025 and the Ghanaian Associations of South Jersey and Atlantic City. The recognition reflected the city’s ongoing commitment to cultural inclusion and the success of historic events like the Ghana Flag Raising Ceremony—the first of its kind in New Jersey.

November also emphasized health and wellness through the Pink Walk for a Purpose, a citywide event for Breast Cancer Awareness Month, where employees joined together to walk in support of survivors and ongoing fighters. Meanwhile, the Re-Entry Services Division held a family reunification event at the All Wars Memorial Building, providing food, fun, and creative activities that brought families closer together.

Finally, Atlantic City Youth Services launched an empowering martial arts program, teaching children the 3 S’s—Self-confidence, Self-reliance, and Self-defense—as part of a series of exciting fall programs designed to engage the city’s youth in positive growth and discipline.

From infrastructure renewal and community celebrations to acts of heroism and cultural recognition, November 2025 stood as another milestone month for Atlantic City—reminding everyone that every day truly is a Great Day in Atlantic City.

item.title: Atlantic City Detectives Complete Specialized Crime Scene Investigation Training
item.dc:creator: Great Day Altantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Police Department congratulated Detectives Brian McKinney and Bryan Victoria-Garcia for completing the New Jersey State Police Crime Scene Investigation Course, further strengthening the department’s investigative and forensic capabilities.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department extended its congratulations to Detectives Brian McKinney and Bryan Victoria-Garcia for the successful completion of the New Jersey State Police Crime Scene Investigation Course.

Over the course of eight weeks, both detectives underwent extensive training designed to deepen their expertise in crime scene analysis and forensic evidence handling. The program covered a wide range of specialized topics including bloodstain pattern analysis, shooting analysis and reconstruction, forensic photography, fingerprint classification and recognition, grave extraction, evidence collection, and courtroom testimony.

This advanced training equipped the detectives with the technical skills necessary to interpret complex crime scenes and present clear, accurate findings in court proceedings.

The New Jersey State Police Crime Scene Investigation Course is known for its rigorous curriculum and hands-on approach, emphasizing the highest standards of forensic science and investigative integrity.

Detectives McKinney and Victoria-Garcia’s participation in this program reflects their commitment to professional development and excellence in law enforcement. Their new skills will play a key role in supporting ongoing investigations and enhancing the department’s ability to bring justice to victims and their families.

With this achievement, the Atlantic City Police Department continues to strengthen its Investigations Division, which now includes multiple detectives trained in specialized forensic techniques.

By investing in continued education and advanced training, the department reaffirms its dedication to maintaining professionalism, precision, and accountability in all investigative operations.

The ACPD commended the detectives for their hard work and dedication, recognizing that their efforts not only elevate the department’s capabilities but also build greater trust and confidence within the Atlantic City community.

The completion of this program marks another step in the department’s ongoing mission to apply modern investigative science in the service of public safety.

Through teamwork, education, and continuous growth, the Atlantic City Police Department remains committed to excellence in protecting and serving the city’s residents.

item.title: City of Atlantic City Reminded Residents to Fall Back and Stay Safe as Daylight Saving Time Ended
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City marked the end of Daylight Saving Time with a timely reminder for residents to set their clocks back one hour and review essential safety measures, including testing smoke detectors and updating emergency plans.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City reminded residents to take note of the time change as Daylight Saving Time officially ended at 2:00 AM on November 2nd. The city encouraged everyone to set their clocks back one hour before going to bed to ensure they stayed on schedule and enjoyed an extra hour of rest.

As part of this seasonal reminder, the City also used the occasion to highlight important home safety practices that should be reviewed during the time change. Residents were urged to test their smoke and carbon monoxide detectors, ensuring that these critical devices were in proper working condition.

In addition, the city recommended that everyone replace old batteries in detectors and other safety devices to help prevent potential hazards. The reminder also extended to checking flashlights and emergency kits, making sure families were well-equipped for any unexpected situation.

The City of Atlantic City encouraged residents to go a step further by reviewing their home safety plans, ensuring every household member knows what to do in case of an emergency. According to the city, this simple routine—coinciding with the clock adjustment—serves as an ideal time to refresh safety habits and strengthen preparedness.

By combining the Fall Back reminder with practical safety advice, the city emphasized the importance of preparedness and awareness within the community. Officials noted that taking just a few minutes to check detectors, update batteries, and review emergency plans could make a significant difference in keeping families safe.

The message served not only as a helpful time adjustment notice but also as a community-wide call to action for safety and readiness. As Atlantic City residents fell back into standard time, they were reminded to stay safe, stay prepared, and take advantage of that extra hour to rest easy knowing their homes and families were protected.

item.title: Join the Fun! Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market Set for December 13
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City’s annual Holiday Parade is back and this year it’s bigger, brighter, and more magical than ever. With a new date, a new route along Atlantic Avenue, and a brand-new Holiday Market at O’Donnell Memorial Park, this year’s celebration promises festive fun, local shopping, and community spirit that will light up the city all season long.
item.content:encoded:
The holiday season in Atlantic City is about to get even more magical. The City of Atlantic City's beloved Holiday Parade is returning this year with new surprises, a fresh route, and a brand-new Holiday Market that promises to fill the city with festive cheer, community spirit, and plenty of reasons to celebrate.

A Parade That Ends in Pure Holiday Magic

This year’s Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market will bring together everything locals love about the season, music, lights, local vendors, and joyful energy.

After the parade, the celebration continues at O’Donnell Memorial Park, where a new Holiday Market will showcase local artisans, handcrafted gifts, festive bites, and seasonal refreshments. Picture twinkling lights, the smell of hot chocolate, and neighbors greeting one another while supporting small businesses — it’s a scene straight out of a holiday movie, right here in Atlantic City.

New Date, Same Holiday Spirit

This year’s parade has been rescheduled to Saturday, December 13, 2025, when, beginning at 4:30 PM, the city will be glowing with holiday lights, creating the perfect backdrop for glowing floats, marching bands, community groups, and dazzling performances. Families are encouraged to bundle up, grab a cup of cocoa, and line the streets to watch Atlantic City come alive with the sights and sounds of the season.

New Route, More Convenience for Families

The parade will travel down Atlantic Avenue from South Carolina Avenue to Albany Avenue, with the staging area at City Hall.

This streamlined route connects directly to O’Donnell Memorial Park, making it easier for families to attend both the parade and the Holiday Market without cross-city travel. It’s a thoughtful touch that ensures everyone can enjoy the festivities together — all in one festive stretch of Atlantic Avenue.

Be Part of the Celebration

Calling all community groups, schools, and local businesses — there’s still time to get involved!
You can:

  • Register a float to join the parade, or
  • Apply to be a vendor at the Holiday Market to showcase your products, crafts, or treats.

To sign up, contact the City of Atlantic City Special Events Office at (609) 347-5823 or visit www.acnj.gov for registration forms.

A Celebration of Community and Local Pride

The Atlantic City Holiday Parade & Market is more than an event — it’s a celebration of togetherness. From community organizations and small businesses to families and visitors, everyone plays a part in making this annual tradition shine brighter each year.

Mark your calendars for Saturday, December 13, 2025 at 4:30 PM, and experience the magic of the season — right here in Atlantic City. Come for the parade, stay for the market, and leave full of holiday joy and Atlantic City pride.

item.title: Atlantic City Celebrates the Grand Opening of Weekes Memorial Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City marked the Grand Opening of Weekes Memorial Park with a ribbon-cutting ceremony celebrating years of dedicated restoration. The revitalized park featured new landscaping, lighting, mosaics, and improved accessibility as part of the Westside Neighborhood’s ongoing renewal.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City proudly celebrated the Grand Opening of Weekes Memorial Park, located at 732 N. Indiana Avenue, with an official ribbon-cutting ceremony. The event marked the successful completion of a long-anticipated restoration project that transformed the area into a vibrant, community-centered green space.

The restoration of Weekes Memorial Park had been years in the making, representing the city’s dedication to enhancing the quality of life for its residents. Through careful planning and collaboration, the city brought new life to this beloved space, ensuring that it would serve as a welcoming environment for recreation, relaxation, and community connection.

Key improvements included newly designed landscaping featuring planted trees and shrubs that added beauty and shade throughout the park. The addition of enhanced lighting improved visibility and safety for visitors, making the park accessible and enjoyable at all hours.

Sustainability was also at the heart of the project. The city prioritized environmental stewardship, integrating features that promoted sustainability and long-term care for the natural surroundings.

Further upgrades included new fencing, which provided both security and structure, and the installation of artistic mosaics and paver displays that added cultural and creative flair to the park’s design. Each artistic detail reflected Atlantic City’s rich diversity and sense of community pride.

In addition to aesthetic improvements, accessibility was a key focus. The park was redesigned to be inclusive, ensuring that residents of all abilities could enjoy the space equally and comfortably.

This project formed an important part of the city’s broader commitment to neighborhood improvement. The park’s reopening was a highlight in the ongoing revitalization of Atlantic City’s Westside Neighborhood, a movement dedicated to enhancing public spaces and building a stronger, more connected community.

With its fresh landscape, sustainable features, and inclusive design, Weekes Memorial Park now stood as a symbol of progress, community spirit, and the city’s continuous efforts to invest in its neighborhoods.

item.title: Atlantic City Makes Steady Progress on Major Paving Projects Across Key Roadways
item.dc:creator: Greay Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City made significant progress on several major paving projects, including completed work on Baltic Avenue and ongoing improvements along MLK Boulevard and Atlantic Avenue. Each milestone brought the city closer to safer and smoother streets for everyone.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City made continued progress in enhancing the quality and safety of its roadways through several major paving projects. The initiative aimed to provide smoother, safer, and more reliable travel experiences for residents and visitors alike.

One of the key updates included Baltic Avenue, where the first half of the milling and paving from Maine to Missouri was officially completed. This marked a major milestone in the city’s infrastructure improvement efforts. Work on the remaining section was set to resume once the stretch of inclement weather passed, ensuring that the project would maintain its pace without compromising quality.

At MLK Boulevard, significant concrete, ramp, and sidewalk improvements were underway. These upgrades were designed to make the area more accessible and pedestrian-friendly, paving the way—literally—for the next phase of work, which included milling and paving from Route 30 to Mediterranean Avenue.

Meanwhile, on Atlantic Avenue, preparations were advancing for the Atlantic Avenue Improvement Project, a major undertaking that covered the stretch from Tennessee to Albany Avenues. The Notice to Proceed had already been issued, and construction submissions were under review. Pre-paving activities were scheduled to start in the following weeks, signaling the beginning of one of the city’s most anticipated roadway transformations.

These coordinated efforts represented the city’s ongoing dedication to maintaining and upgrading its infrastructure. By addressing key routes and ensuring the long-term durability of its roads, the City of Atlantic City demonstrated its commitment to both public safety and community progress.

The paving projects not only improved the driving experience but also contributed to better traffic flow and reduced vehicle wear and tear. Residents were encouraged to stay informed about ongoing updates and traffic advisories to plan their commutes accordingly.

With each completed section, Atlantic City moved closer to achieving its goal of a modern, well-maintained roadway network that supports its growing community and bustling tourism sector.

item.title: Atlantic City Honors the Legacy of Ernest Coursey with a Heartfelt Tribute
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City honored the late Chief of Staff Ernest Coursey with a remembrance walk and the unveiling of a mural at City Hall, celebrating his enduring legacy of leadership, compassion, and community care. His spirit continues to guide and inspire the city each day.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City paid tribute to the life and legacy of its beloved late Chief of Staff, Ernest Coursey, with a heartfelt remembrance dedicated to his enduring impact on the community.

City staff came together for a remembrance walk along the Atlantic City Boardwalk as part of the Coursey Cares Health and Wellness Challenge, an initiative inspired by Coursey’s commitment to health, wellness, and service. The walk served not only as a moment of reflection but also as a continuation of the compassion and community spirit that he so strongly embodied.

The event brought together colleagues, friends, and community members who remembered Coursey as a man of kindness, integrity, and leadership—a figure whose care for others extended beyond his official role and into the hearts of all who knew him.

In addition to the walk, the city unveiled the Ernest Coursey mural, a beautifully crafted artwork now displayed at the employee entrance of City Hall. The mural stands as a lasting reminder of his dedication, leadership, and unwavering love for the City of Atlantic City.

Every brushstroke in the mural represents the vibrancy and warmth that Coursey brought to City Hall. His influence continues to echo in every department, inspiring a new generation of city workers to serve with the same humility and purpose.

Mayor Marty Small Sr. and city officials expressed their gratitude and admiration for Coursey’s years of service and his deep-rooted passion for the community. They highlighted how his work ethic and kindness helped shape the city’s culture of care and unity.

For many, the walk and mural unveiling were emotional reminders that even though Coursey is no longer physically present, his spirit continues to guide and inspire those who had the privilege of working alongside him.

As participants walked the boardwalk, they shared stories, smiles, and moments of silence—each step a symbol of continuity and remembrance. The Coursey Cares Health and Wellness Challenge will carry on in his honor, ensuring his legacy lives through meaningful acts that promote well-being and togetherness.

Through this tribute, Atlantic City reaffirmed its appreciation for a leader who believed in people, progress, and compassion above all else.

Ernest Coursey’s light continues to shine, reminding everyone that true leadership is measured not only in words and actions but in the lasting impact left on the hearts of others.

item.title: Heartwarming Community Workshop at Pennsylvania Avenue School in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Public Schools Early Childhood Department hosted Waffles with the Nurse at Pennsylvania Avenue School, combining a delicious breakfast with vital health education to promote wellness, family engagement, and community connection.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Public Schools Early Childhood Department hosted a warm and engaging community event titled Waffles with the Nurse on Wednesday, October 22, 2025, at Pennsylvania Avenue School. The workshop successfully combined delicious breakfast treats with essential health education, creating an atmosphere of learning, care, and connection among parents, staff, and students.

The event was designed to promote family engagement and raise awareness about student health requirements. Parents gathered in the Parent Resource Center, where they enjoyed freshly made waffles, crispy bacon, sausage, and fruit while participating in an informative discussion about school health policies.

Principal Thomas Biggins emphasized the school’s commitment to family involvement and student well-being, saying, “We’re not just a building on the block. One of our cornerstones is parent involvement. Most importantly, we want students to be healthy, and they need to be well.”

School Nurse Sherese Price led the workshop, focusing on vital topics such as immunizations, physicals, and health documentation. She reminded parents to ensure their child’s contact information and medical records are up-to-date and that flu shots and dental records are submitted as required. “We want your child to be in school, every day,” she said.

Nurse Price also discussed the importance of keeping children home when they are sick, outlining clear health guidelines for families. She addressed seasonal illnesses and emerging health concerns such as Hand, Foot and Mouth disease, reinforcing the importance of prevention and early awareness.

“Nurse Price leads with empathy and care,” said Principal Biggins. “Bringing awareness to everything that a nurse does is absolutely critical.”

The event’s welcoming environment was further enriched by the efforts of Parent Resource Center Educator Denise Bowles, who highlighted the center’s role in supporting families. “We take care of the needs of the parents,” Bowles said, explaining that the center offers English as a Second Language (ESL) classes and family-centered programs like Muffins with Moms and Donuts with Dads.

Waffles with the Nurse was more than just a breakfast gathering—it was a celebration of community, health, and collaboration. The event reflected the district’s dedication to supporting families not only academically but also through wellness and engagement initiatives.

Through events like this, Atlantic City Public Schools continues to strengthen the partnership between educators, health professionals, and families, ensuring that every child has the foundation to thrive in both health and learning.

The success of Waffles with the Nurse demonstrated how meaningful outreach and genuine connection can foster stronger relationships, encourage proactive health habits, and build a more supportive school community.

The luncheon gathered city officials, law enforcement officers, and community members to celebrate those who go above and beyond in protecting and serving the public.

Sergeant Walsh’s bravery stood as a testament to the values of commitment, quick thinking, and compassion that guide the Atlantic City Police Department. His actions not only saved a life but also inspired others in the force and community to uphold the highest standards of public service.

The Atlantic City Police Foundation emphasized that honoring officers like Sgt. Walsh reinforces the importance of recognizing everyday heroes who make a lasting impact on the safety and well-being of the city’s residents and visitors.

Attendees expressed deep appreciation for the dedication of the men and women in uniform, whose courage and professionalism continue to strengthen the bond between law enforcement and the community.

The Hero Luncheon served as both a celebration and a reminder of the sacrifices officers make in the line of duty, often putting others’ safety above their own.

Mayor Marty Small Sr., along with city and police officials, extended congratulations to Sgt. Walsh for his remarkable bravery and unwavering commitment to the people of Atlantic City.

The event also highlighted the collaborative efforts of local organizations, businesses, and civic leaders who support the ongoing mission of the Atlantic City Police Foundation.

item.title: Celebrating Atlantic City’s Business Icons: A Street Dedication to Entrepreneurial Excellence
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kramer
item.description: Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue pays tribute to the couple who owned and operated multiple McDonald’s franchises in Atlantic City for four decades.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City community has been lovin’ longtime Atlantic City McDonald’s owners Rita and Anthony Mack for the last four decades, and they’ve been lovin’ the community right back. And now, the City of Atlantic City has honored these two community icons with a street dedication recognizing their nearly 40 years of business excellence, community impact, and entrepreneurial leadership in the city.

Arctic Avenue between Michigan and Arkansas Avenues has been named Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue, paying tribute to the couple who owned and operated multiple McDonald’s franchises in Atlantic City, with their first one purchased in June 1986 and final one sold in May 2024 as they embarked on a much-deserved retirement.

The Macks are the definition of successful entrepreneurship in Atlantic City. Long before casinos dominated the city’s economy, there was a generation of African American business leaders who built strong, community-based enterprises that anchored neighborhoods and provided opportunity. Today, as Atlantic City’s Economic Development division under the Department of Planning and Development works to revitalize that same spirit of local ownership and empowerment, the Macks stand as living proof that businesses –especially minority-owned ones - can not only survive but thrive in Atlantic City. Rita and Anthony Mack have been the blueprint for success, showing what’s possible through hard work, generosity, and a deep commitment to community.

“We really appreciate your many years of service, your selfless service, and your dedication to the Great City of Atlantic City community," Mayor Small told the Macks during the Street Dedication Ceremony in their honor. It was during this ceremony that the couple also received a custom street sign to take home, symbolizing the enduring legacy they have built.

Rita and Anthony Mack expressed deep gratitude for the recognition and for the community that supported them from the beginning.

“We are incredibly honored and humbled to receive this awesome recognition,” said Rita Mack. “The renaming of this city block to Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue is an undeniable dream for us. It’s the very block where we began our business journey in 1986, and we are thrilled beyond belief.”

Reflecting on their journey, Rita added:

“They say the most critical factors in choosing a franchise are location, location, location. I must say, we struck gold when we purchased our Arkansas Avenue site. But we were also blessed to find ourselves in a supportive and caring community. From the very beginning, this community has embraced and supported us in so many ways.”

The Macks hope that others — especially young people and aspiring entrepreneurs — will be inspired each time they pass Rita and Anthony Mack Avenue, a lasting reminder that dreams can be built right here in Atlantic City.

Their name now rightfully takes its place in the heart of Atlantic City in recognition of their extraordinary contributions.
